, Egypt's antiquities chief, toured the complex yesterday and expressed confidence it was sufficiently protected. Mr Zahi Hawass , who was appointed minister of state antiquities yesterday as part of the cabinet reshuffle, said: If the museum is safe, Egypt is safe. Looters were able to break into the museum on Friday, ripping the heads off two mummies and damaging about 75 small artefacts before soldiers caught them. Mr Zahi Hawass said the broken artefacts could be restored.

While protesters dismissed the Cabinet reshuffle as cosmetic and demanded Hosni Mubarak 's immediate ouster, Zahi Hawass said Egyptians should give his boss more time. The people in the streets have to give this government an opportunity to change, he said cheerfully.`` Beautiful things happened in the last five days.'' . Zahi Hawass wrote, in a post to his Web site, which, due to the blocked Internet access at the time, he had to fax to colleagues in Italy to upload: My heart is broken and my blood is boiling.
